required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy Study Measuring the Impact of Pregabalin on Peripheral Neuropathic Pain.
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Placebo-Controlled Trial of the Efficacy and Safety of Pregabalin in the Treatment of Subjects With Peripheral Neuropathic Pain

brief_summary.textblock: This study will measure the impact of treatment with pregabalin in adult men and women who have a diagnosis of peripheral neuropathic pain (pain caused by a primary lesion of the peripheral nervous system such as Diabetic peripheral Neuropathy and Postherpetic Neuralgia).

primary_outcome.measure: Neuropathic Pain in Subjects With Peripheral Neuropathic Pain Conditions During the Double-blind Phase
primary_outcome.description: Pain score end of Double-Blind treatment = mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on Double-Blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11- point numerical scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain").

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Mean Pain Scores During the Single-blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Pain score at Week 0 and Week 4, end of single-bind treatment. Mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on single-blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11- point numerical scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain").

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Mean Pain Scores During the Double Blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Mean Pain scores for weeks 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9. Mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on single-blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11-point numerical scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain").

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Pain Scores During Double Blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Change in Mean Pain score = Mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on single-blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11-point numerical scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain").

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Subjects With >= 30% Reduction in Mean Pain Score During Single-blind Treatment
secondary_outcome.description: Responders = ≥30% reduction in mean pain score at end of single-blind treatment phase compared to weekly mean pain score at baseline. Mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on single-blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11-point numerical scale ranging from 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain").

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Pain Score for Responders at End of Single-blind Treatment Phase. Change From Baseline of Mean of Last 7 Available Pain Scores From Daily Pain Diary While on Single-blind Treatment.
secondary_outcome.description: Daily Pain Rating Score:11-point numerical scale 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain"). Responders = ≥30% reduction in mean pain score at end of single-blind treatment phase compared to weekly mean pain score at baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Pain Score for Non-responders at End of Single-blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline of mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on single-blind treatment. Daily Pain Rating Score:11-point numerical scale 0 ("no pain") to 10 ("worst possible pain"). Non-Responders = <30% reduction in mean pain score at end of single-blind treatment phase compared to weekly mean pain score at baseline.
Mean number of days in each pain category. DPRS Daily Pain Rating Score Categories: No pain (score 0), Mild pain (scores 1-3), Moderate pain (scores 4-6), Severe pain (scores 7-10)

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Meaningful Increase in Pain During Double-blind Treatment Phase (Number of Participants)
secondary_outcome.description: Number of participants who experienced a meaningful increase in pain also includes participants who took rescue medication for pain due to peripheral neuropathic pain or discontinued from the study .

Mean Sleep Interference (SI) score at end of Double-Blind treatment = mean of last 7 available SI scores from daily SI diary while on Double-Blind treatment. Daily SI rating scale (DSIS) consists of an 11-point numerical scale : Zero means "pain does not interfere with sleep" and 10 means "pain completely interferes with sleep."

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Mean Sleep Interference Scores During the Single-Blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Sleep Interference (SI) score at Week 0 and Week 4, end of single-bind treatment. Mean of last 7 available SI scores from daily SI diary while on single-blind treatment. Daily SI rating scale (DSIS) consists of an 11-point numerical scale : Zero means "pain does not interfere with sleep" and 10 means "pain completely interferes with sleep."

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Mean Sleep Interference Scores During the Double Blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Mean Sleep Interference scores for weeks 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 and 9. Mean of last 7 available SI scores from daily SI diary while on single-blind treatment. Daily SI rating scale (DSIS) consists of an 11-point numerical scale : Zero means "pain does not interfere with sleep" and 10 means "pain completely interferes with sleep."

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Sleep Interference Scores During Double Blind Treatment Phase
secondary_outcome.description: Change in Mean SI score: Mean SI score at observation minus mean SI score at week 4. Mean SI Score = mean of last 7 available SI scores from daily SI diary while on single-blind treatment. Daily SI rating scale (DSIS) is 11-point numerical scale : Zero means "pain does not interfere with sleep" and 10 means "pain completely interferes with sleep."

secondary_outcome.measure: Intensity of Neuropathic Pain -Visual Analog Scale (NeP - VAS)
secondary_outcome.description: Change in Scale from randomization to Week 9. Scale to measure Neuropathic Pain -Visual Analog Scale (NeP - VAS): the subject places a mark on the VAS scale (0 to 100) where 0 represents the worst imaginable health state and 100 represents the best imaginable health state.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale Responses
secondary_outcome.description: Mean Change from Randomization in Score from Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS): 2 subscales, measuring anxiety (HADS-A)and depression (HADS-D). 7 items in each subscale assessed on a scale of 0 (no presence of anxiety or depression) to 3 (severe feeling of anxiety or depression). which yields the score ranging 0-21.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Pain Treatment Satisfaction Scale (PTSS)
secondary_outcome.description: Mean Change: score from observation minus score from randomization: PTSS "Impact" module of 8-items & "Satisfaction" module of 6-items; item scores 1-5. Mean score for each module transformed onto scale 0- 100, where score 0 =worst possible response and score 100 =best possible response: Score =[(5 - mean non-missing items)*100]/4.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Categories by Number of Subjects
secondary_outcome.description: Number of subjects that responded to PGIC Categories. PGIC is a subject-rated instrument that measures change in the subject's overall status on a 7-point scale. Scores range from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Modified Brief Pain Inventory (mBPI) for Pain Interference or Pain Severity.
secondary_outcome.description: Mean Change from Randomization: score at mBPI observation minus score at randomization. mBPI is extent to which pain interferes with daily activities on a 0 (no interference) to 10 (completely interfered) scale.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Euro Quality of Life (EQ-5D) Health State Profile and Visual Analog Scale Components
secondary_outcome.description: two components to the EQ-5D: a Health State Profile (scores from five domains are used to calculate the utility score :0 refers to dead and a score of 1 refers to perfect health) and a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) (0 represents the worst imaginable health state and 100 represents the best imaginable health state)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects presenting a diagnosis of peripheral neuropathic pain, defined as pain caused by a lesion of the peripheral nervous system manifesting with sensory symptoms and signs, for at least 6 months at screening.
- At baseline, subjects must have completed at least 4 daily pain diaries and must have a mean weekly pain score equal or greater than 4.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of any of the following diagnoses: Cervical or lumbo-sacral radiculopathy; Operated or non-operated chronic low back pain Carpal tunnel syndrome or any other entrapment-related neuropathic pain (defined as pain associated with focal nerve lesion produced by constriction or mechanical distortion of the nerve, within a fibrous or fibro-osseous tunnel, or by a fibrous band) ; Complex regional pain syndrome (type 1 and 2); Fibromyalgia.

link.description: To obtain contact information for a study center near you, click here.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: This study was conducted in Canada.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 405 subjects enrolled - 234 completed the single-blind phase. Subjects who responded (≥30% decrease in weekly mean pain score) during single-blind entered double-blind. 158 subjects assigned to study drug in double-blind phase. One subject in placebo group was randomized in error, not treated, not included as discontinuation;157 received treatment.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

measure.title: Age
Gender

outcome.title: Neuropathic Pain in Subjects With Peripheral Neuropathic Pain Conditions During the Double-blind Phase
outcome.description: Pain score end of Double-Blind treatment = mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on Double-Blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11- point numerical scale ranging from 0 (“no pain”) to 10 (“worst possible pain”).
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set (FAS) = Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population, defined as all subjects who are randomized into the Double-Blind treatment phase, who receive at least one dose of Double-Blind study medication and complete at least one postrandomization efficacy assessment.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

measure.title: Neuropathic Pain in Subjects With Peripheral Neuropathic Pain Conditions During the Double-blind Phase
measure.description: Pain score end of Double-Blind treatment = mean of last 7 available pain scores from daily pain diary while on Double-Blind treatment. A Daily Pain Rating Score : 11- point numerical scale ranging from 0 (“no pain”) to 10 (“worst possible pain”).
measure.population: Full Analysis Set (FAS) = Intent-to-Treat (ITT) population, defined as all subjects who are randomized into the Double-Blind treatment phase, who receive at least one dose of Double-Blind study medication and complete at least one postrandomization efficacy assessment.

analysis.groups_desc: The study is powered to detect clinically significant difference of 1.2 between treatment groups in mean pain score at end of treatment. The statistical sample size calculation requires a total of 144 subjects to complete the Double-Blind phase of the study: a sample size of 72 in each treatment group will have 90% power to detect a difference in treatment mean pain scores of 1.2 assuming that the common standard deviation is 2.2 using a two group t-test with a 0.05 two-sided significance level.

outcome.title: Weekly Mean Sleep Interference Scores During the Single-Blind Treatment Phase
outcome.description: Sleep Interference (SI) score at Week 0 and Week 4, end of single-bind treatment. Mean of last 7 available SI scores from daily SI diary while on single-blind treatment. Daily SI rating scale (DSIS) consists of an 11-point numerical scale : Zero means “pain does not interfere with sleep” and 10 means “pain completely interferes with sleep.”
outcome.population: Last observation carried forward (LOCF) approach for patients who do not complete the study will be adopted. This is defined as the mean of the last 7 diary scores while on Double-Blind study drug, up to and including the day after the last day on drug (excluding the taper phase).

measure.description: Mean Change from Randomization in Score from Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS): 2 subscales, measuring anxiety (HADS-A)and depression (HADS-D). 7 items in each subscale assessed on a scale of 0 (no presence of anxiety or depression) to 3 (severe feeling of anxiety or depression). which yields the score ranging 0-21.

outcome.title: Change in Pain Treatment Satisfaction Scale (PTSS)
outcome.description: Mean Change: score from observation minus score from randomization: PTSS “Impact” module of 8-items & “Satisfaction” module of 6-items; item scores 1-5. Mean score for each module transformed onto scale 0- 100, where score 0 =worst possible response and score 100 =best possible response: Score =[(5 – mean non-missing items)*100]/4.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

measure.title: Change in Pain Treatment Satisfaction Scale (PTSS)
measure.description: Mean Change: score from observation minus score from randomization: PTSS “Impact” module of 8-items & “Satisfaction” module of 6-items; item scores 1-5. Mean score for each module transformed onto scale 0- 100, where score 0 =worst possible response and score 100 =best possible response: Score =[(5 – mean non-missing items)*100]/4.

outcome.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Categories by Number of Subjects
outcome.description: Number of subjects that responded to PGIC Categories. PGIC is a subject-rated instrument that measures change in the subject’s overall status on a 7-point scale. Scores range from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

measure.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC) Categories by Number of Subjects
measure.description: Number of subjects that responded to PGIC Categories. PGIC is a subject-rated instrument that measures change in the subject’s overall status on a 7-point scale. Scores range from 1 (very much improved) to 7 (very much worse).

analysis.groups_desc: The distribution of the responses to the PGIC at EOT was compared between the 2 treatment groups using the 7 categories of the PGIC.

outcome.title: Change in Modified Brief Pain Inventory (mBPI) for Pain Interference or Pain Severity.
outcome.description: Mean Change from Randomization: score at mBPI observation minus score at randomization. mBPI is extent to which pain interferes with daily activities on a 0 (no interference) to 10 (completely interfered) scale.

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

measure.title: Change in Modified Brief Pain Inventory (mBPI) for Pain Interference or Pain Severity.
measure.description: Mean Change from Randomization: score at mBPI observation minus score at randomization. mBPI is extent to which pain interferes with daily activities on a 0 (no interference) to 10 (completely interfered) scale.

outcome.title: Change in Euro Quality of Life (EQ-5D) Health State Profile and Visual Analog Scale Components
outcome.description: two components to the EQ-5D: a Health State Profile (scores from five domains are used to calculate the utility score :0 refers to dead and a score of 1 refers to perfect health) and a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) (0 represents the worst imaginable health state and 100 represents the best imaginable health state)

group.title: Pregabalin
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatment phase.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day), starting at 150 mg/day for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

measure.title: Change in Euro Quality of Life (EQ-5D) Health State Profile and Visual Analog Scale Components
measure.description: two components to the EQ-5D: a Health State Profile (scores from five domains are used to calculate the utility score :0 refers to dead and a score of 1 refers to perfect health) and a Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) (0 represents the worst imaginable health state and 100 represents the best imaginable health state)

group.title: Pregabalin Single-blind Phase
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day) for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed.

group.title: Pregabalin Double-blind Phase
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day) for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to pregabalin entered the double-blind phase with 35 days of dose achieved at the end of the single-blind treatent phase.

group.title: Placebo Double-blind Phase
group.description: subjects entered single-blind phase with 28 days of single-blind flexible pregabalin doses (150 to 600 mg/day) for ≥4 days, then dose adjustment as needed. Subjects who responded during the single-blind phase and were randomized to placebo received pregabalin 150 mg for 7 days and then placebo for 28 days.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Pfizer has the right to review disclosures, requesting a delay of <60 days. Investigator will postpone single center publications until after disclosure of pooled data (all sites), <12 mo from study completion/termination at all participating sites. Investigator may not disclose previously undisclosed confidential info other than study results.
